Henry]], [[Victor Hugo]], [[H.L. Mencken]], [[Ludwig von Mises]], [[Friedrich Nietzsche]], [[Isabel Paterson]] | influenced = [[Martin Anderson (economist)|Martin Anderson]], [[Bob Barr]], [[Andrew Bernstein]], [[Harry Binswanger]], [[Barbara Branden]], [[Nathaniel Branden]], [[Steve Ditko]], [[Edith Efron]], [[Terry Goodkind]], [[Allan Gotthelf]], [[Alan Greenspan]], [[Robert Hessen]], [[Erika Holzer]], [[John Hospers]], [[David Kelley]], [[Anton LaVey]], [[Liu Junning]], [[Edwin A. Locke]], [[Tibor Machan]], [[Stefan Molyneux]], [[Ron Paul]], [[Neil Peart]], [[Leonard Peikoff]], [[George Reisman]], [[Murray Rothbard]], [[John Ridpath]], [[Paul Ryan (politician)|Paul Ryan]], [[Chris Matthew Sciabarra]], [[George H. Smith]], [[Kay Nolte Smith]], [[L. Neil Smith]], [[Tara Smith (philosopher)|Tara Smith]], [[John Stossel]] [[Clarence Thomas]], [[Jimmy Wales]] | notableworks = ''[[The Fountainhead]]''
''[[Atlas Shrugged]]'' | signature=Sign Ayn Rand.png }} '''Ayn Rand''' ({{IPA-en|ˈaɪn ˈrænd|pron}};{{cite web |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/PageServer?pagename=about_ayn_rand_faq_index2#ar_q3 |title=Frequently Asked Questions About Ayn Rand: How do you pronounce 'Ayn'? |publisher=[[Ayn Rand Institute]] |accessdate=February 6, 2010}} born '''Alisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum''', {{OldStyleDate|February 2|1905|January 20}} – March 6, 1982), was a [[Russian-American]] [[novelist]], [[philosopher]],The following sources identify Rand as a philosopher: * {{harvnb|Saxon|1982|p=36}}. "Ayn Rand, the writer and philosopher of objectivism who espoused 'rational selfishness' and capitalism unbound, died yesterday morning at her home on East 34th Street." * "Preface" in {{harvnb|Den Uyl|Rasmussen|1986|p=x}}. "... this book is devoted to an assessment of Ayn Rand the philosopher. All the contributors to this volume agree that she is a philosopher and not a mere popularizer. Moreover, all agree that many of her insights on philosophy and her own philosophic ideas deserve critical attention by professional philosophers, whatever the final merit of those inquiries and theories. It is appropriate, therefore, that all our contributors are themselves professional philosophers." * {{harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|p=1}}. "Ayn Rand is one of the most widely read philosophers of the twentieth century." * {{harvnb|Kukathas|1998|p=55}}. "Ayn Rand was a Russian-born novelist and philosopher who exerted considerable influence in the conservative and libertarian intellectual movements in the post-war USA." * {{harvnb|Badhwar|Long|2010}}. "Ayn Rand (1905–1982) was a philosopher and a novelist who outlined a comprehensive philosophy, including an epistemology and a theory of art, in her novels and essays." [[playwright]], and [[screenwriter]]. She is known for her two best-selling novels and for developing a philosophical system she called [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivism]]. Born and educated in Russia, Rand migrated to the United States in 1926. She worked as a screenwriter in [[Hollywood]] and had a play produced on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in 1935–1936. She first achieved fame with her 1943 novel ''[[The Fountainhead]]''. Over a decade later, she published her ''magnum opus'', the philosophical novel ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]'', in 1957. Rand's political views, reflected in both her fiction and nonfiction work, emphasize [[individual rights]] (including property rights) and [[laissez-faire]] [[capitalism]], enforced by a constitutionally [[limited government]]. She was a fierce opponent of all forms of [[collectivism]] and [[statism]],{{cite journal |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=The Only Path to Tomorrow |journal=[[Reader's Digest]] |month=January |year=1944 |volume=44 |issue=261 |pages=88–90 |url=http://fare.tunes.org/liberty/library/toptt.html}} Reprinted in{{cite book |first=Ayn |last=Rand |title=The Ayn Rand Column |publisher=Second Renaissance Books |location=Oceanside, California |year=1991 |isbn=1-56114-099-6 |oclc=26061978 |editor-first=Peter |editor-last=Schwartz |editor-link=Peter Schwartz (writer) |pages=105–108}}"Racism" in {{harvnb|Rand|1964|p=149}} including [[fascism]], [[communism]], [[socialism]], and the [[welfare state]],{{cite book |title=[[Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal]] |chapter="Extremism," or The Art of Smearing |page=180 |isbn=0-451-14795-2 |year=1967 |location=New York |publisher=Signet |oclc=24916193 |last=Rand |first=Ayn}} and promoted [[ethical egoism]] while rejecting the [[Altruism (ethics)|ethic of altruism]]."Introduction" in {{harvnb|Rand|1964|p=ix}} She considered [[reason]] to be the only means of acquiring [[knowledge]] and its advocacy the most important aspect of her philosophy,{{cite book |title=[[Return of the Primitive: The Anti-Industrial Revolution]] |chapter=The Left: Old and New |page=62 |isbn=0-452-01184-1 |oclc=39281836 |year=1999 |location=New York |publisher=Meridian |last=Rand |first=Ayn |others=Edited by Peter Schwartz}} stating, "I am not ''primarily'' an advocate of capitalism, but of egoism; and I am not ''primarily'' an advocate of egoism, but of reason. If one recognizes the supremacy of reason and applies it consistently, all the rest follows."{{cite journal |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=Brief Summary |journal=[[The Objectivist]] |month=September |year=1971 |volume=10 |issue=9 |page=1}} ==Life and work== ===Early life=== Rand was born Alisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum ({{lang-ru|Алиса Зиновьевна Розенбаум}}) on February 2, 1905, to a [[bourgeois]] family living in [[Saint Petersburg]]. She was the eldest of the three daughters of Zinovy Zakharovich Rosenbaum and Anna Borisovna Rosenbaum, largely non-observant [[Jews]]. Her younger sisters were Natasha and Nora. Rand's father was educated at [[Warsaw University]] as a [[chemist]] and became a successful pharmacist, eventually owning his own pharmacy and the building in which it was located.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=3–5}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=2–3}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=9}} His success allowed the family to employ a cook, maid, nurse, and [[governess]].{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=5}} Growing up, she was praised by adults for her intelligence, but her intensity and social awkwardness meant she rarely had friends her own age. On one occasion, when a school assignment called for her to write about the joys of childhood, she instead wrote what she later recalled as "a scathing denunciation" of childhood as inferior to the intellectual condition of adults.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=11–27}} Rand was twelve at the time of the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]], during which Rand's sympathies were with [[Alexander Kerensky]]. Rand's family life was disrupted by the rise of the [[Bolshevik]] party under [[Vladimir Lenin]]. Her father's pharmacy was confiscated by the Bolsheviks, and the family fled to the [[Crimea]], which was initially under the control of the [[White Army]] during the [[Russian Civil War]]. She later recalled that while in high school she determined that she was an [[atheist]] and that she valued reason above any other human attribute. After graduating from high school in the Crimea, at sixteen Rand returned with her family to Saint Petersburg, where they faced desperate conditions, on occasion, nearly starving.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=35–39}}{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=14–20}} [[File:Twelvecollegia.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A black-and-white engraving shows a large building along the bank of a river, with numerous people and carriages nearby|Rand completed a three-year program at [[Saint Petersburg State University|Petrograd State University]].]] ===University education=== After the Russian Revolution, universities were opened to women, including Jews, allowing Rand to be in the first group of women to enroll at [[Saint Petersburg State University|Petrograd State University]],{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=15}} where she studied in the department of [[social pedagogy]], majoring in history.{{cite journal |last=Sciabarra |first=Chris Matthew |url=http://www.nyu.edu/projects/sciabarra/essays/randt2.htm |title=The Rand Transcript |journal=[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]] |volume=1 |issue=1 |year=1999 |month=Fall |pages=1–26}} At the university she was introduced to the writings of [[Aristotle]] and [[Plato]], who would form two of the greatest influences and counter-influences respectively on her thought.{{harvnb|Peikoff|1991|pp=451–460}} A third figure whose philosophical works she studied heavily was [[Friedrich Nietzsche]].{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=17–18, 22–24}} Able to read French, German and Russian, at this time she also discovered the fiction writers [[Fyodor Dostoevsky]], [[Victor Hugo]], [[Edmond Rostand]], and [[Friedrich Schiller]], who became her perennial favorites.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=17, 22}} Along with many other "bourgeois" students, Rand was purged from the university shortly before graduating. However, after complaints from a group of visiting foreign scientists, many of the purged students were allowed to complete their work and graduate,{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=47}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=24}} which Rand did in October 1924. She subsequently studied for a year at the State [[Technicum]] for Screen Arts in Leningrad. For one of her assignments, she wrote an essay about the actress [[Pola Negri]], which became her first published work.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=49–50}} By this time she had decided her professional surname for writing would be ''Rand'',{{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=33}} possibly as a [[Cyrillic]] [[contraction (grammar)|contraction]] of her birth surname,{{cite web |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/PageServer?pagename=about_ayn_rand_faq_index2#ar_q3b |title=Frequently Asked Questions About Ayn Rand: What is the origin of “Rand”? |publisher=Ayn Rand Institute |accessdate=April 2, 2010}} and she adopted the first name ''Ayn'', either from a Finnish name or from the Hebrew word {{lang|he| עין}} (''ayin'', meaning "eye").Rand said the origin of ''Ayn'' was Finnish {{harv|Rand|1995|p=40}}, but some biographical sources question this, suggesting it may come from a Hebrew nickname. {{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=55–57}} provides a detailed discussion. ===In the United States=== In fall 1925, she was granted a [[Visa (document)|visa]] to visit American relatives. As her train pulled away she called out to her family, "By the time I return, I'll be famous!" Leaving Russia on January 17, 1926, Rand arrived in the United States on February 19, entering by ship through [[New York City]].{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=50–53}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=30}} She was so impressed with the skyline of [[Manhattan]] upon her arrival that she cried what she later called "tears of splendor".{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=53}} Intent on staying in the United States to become a screenwriter, she lived for a few months with relatives in [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], one of whom owned a movie theater and allowed her to watch dozens of films for free. She then set out for [[Hollywood, California]].{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=57–60}} Initially, she struggled in Hollywood and took odd jobs to pay her basic living expenses. A chance meeting with famed director [[Cecil B. DeMille]] led to a job as an [[extra (drama)|extra]] in his film, ''[[The King of Kings (1927 film)|The King of Kings]]'', and to subsequent work as a junior screenwriter.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=34–36}} While working on ''The King of Kings'', she intentionally bumped into an aspiring young actor, Frank O'Connor, who caught her eye. The two were married on April 15, 1929. Rand [[United States nationality law#Naturalization|became an American citizen]] in 1931. Taking various jobs during the 1930s to support her writing, Rand worked for a time as the head of the costume department at [[RKO]] Studios.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=35–40}}; {{harvnb|Paxton|1998|pp=74, 81, 84}} She made several attempts to bring her parents and sisters to the United States, but they were unable to get permission to emigrate.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=96–98}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=43–44, 52}} [[File:Pola Negri by Ayn Rand cover.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A brown book cover with black-and-white drawings and text in Russian. The drawing on the left is a portrait of a woman with dark hair; the drawing on the right is of skyscrapers.|Cover of Rand's first book, a 2,500-word monograph on the Polish ''femme fatale'' [[Pola Negri]] published in 1925.]] ===Early fiction=== {{See also|Night of January 16th|We the Living|Anthem (novella)}} In the late 1920s, Rand worked on a number of writing projects, including movie scenarios, short stories, and a novel called ''The Little Street''.{{harvnb|Rand|1997|pp=3, 20}} In notes for the novel that Rand scholars have interpreted as evidence of a qualified admiration for the ideas of [[Friedrich Nietzsche]],{{harvnb|Rand|1997|pp=21}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=24–25}};{{cite journal |title=A Renaissance in Rand Scholarship |last=Sciabarra |first=Chris Matthew |authorlink=Chris Matthew Sciabarra |journal=Reason Papers |volume=23 |month=Fall |year=1998 |pages=132–159 |url=http://www.nyu.edu/projects/sciabarra/essays/rprev.htm}};{{cite journal |title=Ronald E. Merrill and the Discovery of Ayn Rand's Nietzschean Period |last=Reed |first=Adam |journal=[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]] |volume=10 |month=Spring |year=2009 |pages=325–326 |issue=2}} the hero of ''The Little Street'' was described as having "the true, innate psychology of a Superman" and was to be based on the case of child killer [[William Edward Hickman]], who Rand described as "a brilliant, unusual, exceptional boy turned into a purposeless monster" by a society that then turned on him as a mob, not because of his crime but because of "his immense, explicit egoism".{{harvnb|Rand|1997|pp=27–39}}. Rand later abandoned both the novel and her positive view of Nietzsche, and most of these early projects were never produced or published during Rand's lifetime. Rand's first literary success came with the sale of her screenplay ''[[Red Pawn]]'' to [[Universal Studios]] in 1932. [[Josef Von Sternberg]] considered it for [[Marlene Dietrich]], but [[anti-Communist]] themes were unpopular at the time, and the project came to nothing.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=40, 42}} This was followed by the courtroom drama ''[[Night of January 16th]]'', first produced in Hollywood in 1934 and then successfully reopened on [[Broadway theater|Broadway]] in 1935. Each night the "jury" was selected from members of the audience, and one of the two different endings, depending on the jury's "verdict", would then be performed.{{harvnb|Rand|1971|pp=3–11}} In 1941, [[Paramount Pictures]] produced a movie version of the play. Rand did not participate in the production and was highly critical of the result.{{cite book |title=The Fountainheads: Wright, Rand, the FBI and Hollywood |last=Johnson |first=Donald Leslie |location=Jefferson, North Carolina |publisher=McFarland & Company |year=2005 |isbn=0-7864-1958-X |oclc=56617298 |pages=55–56}} ''cf''. {{harvnb|Rand|1971|pp=13–14}} Her first novel, the semi-autobiographical ''[[We the Living]]'', was published in 1936. Set in [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]], it focused on the struggle between the individual and the state. In the foreword to the novel, Rand stated that ''We the Living'' "is as near to an autobiography as I will ever write. It is not an autobiography in the literal, but only in the intellectual sense. The plot is invented, the background is not..."{{cite book |last=Rand |first=Ayn |chapter=Foreword |title=We The Living |location=New York |publisher=Dutton |page=xviii |isbn=0-525-94054-5 |oclc=32780458 |edition=60th Anniversary |year=1995 |origyear=1936}} Without Rand's knowledge or permission, ''We the Living'' was made into a pair of [[Italy|Italian]] films, ''Noi vivi'' and ''Addio, Kira'', in 1942. Rediscovered in the 1960s, these films were re-edited into a new version which was approved by Rand and re-released as ''We the Living'' in 1986.{{harvnb|Paxton|1998|p=104}} Her novella ''[[Anthem (novella)|Anthem]]'' was published in England in 1938 and in America seven years later.{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=11}} It presents a vision of a [[dystopian]] future world in which [[totalitarianism|totalitarian]] collectivism has triumphed to such an extent that even the word 'I' has been forgotten and replaced with 'we'.{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=29}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=50}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=102}} ===''The Fountainhead'' and political activism=== {{See also|The Fountainhead|The Fountainhead (film)}} {{Quote box |quote=The great creators—the thinkers, the artists, the scientists, the inventors—stood alone against the men of their time. Every great new thought was opposed. Every great new invention was denounced. The first motor was considered foolish. The airplane was considered impossible. The power loom was considered vicious. Anesthesia was considered sinful. But the men of unborrowed vision went ahead. They fought, they suffered and they paid. But they won. |source=[[Howard Roark]], in ''[[The Fountainhead]]''{{cite book |title=[[The Fountainhead]] |first=Ayn |last=Rand |publisher=Signet |location=New York |isbn=0-451-19115-3 |year=1996 |origyear=1943 |page=710}} |width=28% |align=right |salign=right |quoted=true}} During the 1940s, Rand became involved in political activism. Both she and her husband worked full time in volunteer positions for the 1940 Presidential campaign of Republican [[Wendell Willkie]]. This work led to Rand's first public speaking experiences, including fielding the sometimes hostile questions from New York City audiences who had just viewed pro-Willkie newsreels, an experience she greatly enjoyed.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=57}} This activity also brought her into contact with other intellectuals sympathetic to free-market capitalism. She became friends with journalist [[Henry Hazlitt]] and his wife, and Hazlitt introduced her to the [[Austrian School]] economist [[Ludwig von Mises]]. Despite her philosophical differences with them, Rand strongly endorsed the writings of both men throughout her career, and both of them expressed admiration for her. Once von Mises referred to Rand as "the most courageous man in America," a compliment that particularly pleased her because he said "man" instead of "woman."{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=114}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=249}}; {{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=188–189}} Following the publication of ''Atlas Shrugged'', Mises invited Rand to participate in his economics seminar as his "honored guest," which she did.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=177}} Rand also developed a friendship with [[libertarian]] writer [[Isabel Paterson]]. Rand questioned the well-informed Paterson about American history and politics long into the night during their numerous meetings and gave Paterson ideas for her only nonfiction book, ''[[The God of the Machine]]''.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=75–78}} Rand's first major success as a writer came with ''[[The Fountainhead]]'' in 1943, a romantic and philosophical novel that she wrote over a period of seven years.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=61–78}} The novel centers on an uncompromising young [[architect]] named [[Howard Roark]] and his struggle against what Rand described as "second-handers"—those who attempt to live through others, placing others above self. It was rejected by twelve publishers before finally being accepted by the [[Bobbs-Merrill Company]] on the insistence of editor Archibald Ogden, who threatened to quit if his employer did not publish it.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=58–61}} While completing the novel, Rand was prescribed the [[amphetamine]] [[Benzedrine]] to fight fatigue.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=85}} The drug helped her to work long hours to meet her deadline for delivering the finished novel, but when the book was done, she was so exhausted that her doctor ordered two weeks' rest.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=89}} Her continued use of the drug for a number of years may have contributed to what some of her later associates described as volatile mood swings.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=178}}; {{harvnb|Heller|pp=304–305}} ''The Fountainhead'' eventually became a worldwide success, bringing Rand fame and financial security.According to the [[Ayn Rand Institute]], by April 2008 the novel had sold over 6.5 million copies.{{cite web |title=Sales of Ayn Rand Books Reach 25 million Copies |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/News2?page=NewsArticle&id=17345 |date=April 7, 2008 |accessdate=July 31, 2009 |publisher=Ayn Rand Institute}} In 1943, Rand sold the rights for a [[The Fountainhead (film)|film version]] to [[Warner Brothers]], and she returned to Hollywood to write the screenplay. Finishing her work on that screenplay, she was hired by producer [[Hal Wallis]] as a screenwriter and script-doctor. Her work for Wallis included the screenplays for the [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-nominated [[Love Letters (1945 film)|''Love Letters'']] and ''[[You Came Along]]'', along with research for a screenplay based on the development of the [[Nuclear Weapon|atomic bomb]].{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=68–80}}; {{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=183–198}} This role gave Rand time to work on other projects, including the publication of her first work of nonfiction, an essay titled "The Only Path to Tomorrow", in the January 1944 edition of ''[[Reader's Digest]]'' magazine. Rand also outlined and took extensive notes for a nonfiction treatment of her philosophy, although the planned book was never completed.{{harvnb|Rand|1997|pp=243–310}} While working in Hollywood, Rand extended her involvement with [[free-market]] and [[anti-Communist]] activism. She and her husband purchased a [[Von Sternberg House|house]] designed by modernist [[Richard Neutra]] and an adjoining ranch. There, Rand entertained figures such as Hazlitt, [[Morrie Ryskind]], [[Barbara Stanwyck]], [[Janet Gaynor]], [[Adrian (costume designer)|Adrian]], [[Albert Mannheimer]] and [[Leonard Read]]. A visit by Isabel Paterson to meet with Rand's California associates led to a final falling out between the two when Paterson made comments that Rand saw as rude to valued political allies.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=130–131}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=214–215}}; {{harvnb|Rand|1997|p=131}} Despite their break, Rand continued to promote Paterson's ''The God of the Machine''.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=217}} {{Wikisource|Ayn Rand's testimony before the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities}} Rand became involved with the [[Motion Picture Alliance for the Preservation of American Ideals]], a Hollywood anti-Communist group, and wrote articles on the group's behalf.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=100, 123}} She also joined the anti-Communist [[American Writers Association]].{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=101}} In 1947, during the [[Second Red Scare]], Rand testified as a "friendly witness" before the United States [[House Un-American Activities Committee]]. Her testimony described the disparity between her personal experiences in the [[Soviet Union]] and the portrayal of it in the 1944 film ''[[Song of Russia]]''.{{harvnb|Mayhew|2005|pp=91–93}} Rand argued that the film grossly misrepresented conditions in the Soviet Union, portraying life there as being much better and happier than it actually was."[http://www.capmag.com/article.asp?ID=12 Ayn Rand's HUAC Testimony]" in {{harvnb|Mayhew|2005|pp=188–189}} When asked about her feelings on the effectiveness of the investigations after the hearings, Rand described the process as "futile".{{harvnb|Mayhew|2005|p=83}} After several delays, the movie version of ''The Fountainhead'' was released in 1949. Although it used Rand's screenplay with minimal alterations, she "disliked the movie from beginning to end," complaining about its editing, acting and other elements.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=71}} ===''Atlas Shrugged'' and Objectivism=== {{See also|Atlas Shrugged|Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivist movement}} {{Quote box |quote=The man at the top of the intellectual pyramid contributes the most to all those below him, but gets nothing except his material payment, receiving no intellectual bonus from others to add to the value of his time. The man at the bottom who, left to himself, would starve in his hopeless ineptitude, contributes nothing to those above him, but receives the bonus of all their brains. Such is the nature of the competition between the strong and the weak of the intellect. Such is the pattern of 'exploitation' for which you have damned the strong.|source=[[John Galt]], in ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]''{{harvnb|Rand|1992|p=1065}} |width=32% |align=right |salign=right |quoted=true}} After the publication of ''The Fountainhead'', Rand received numerous letters from readers, some of whom it had profoundly influenced. In 1951 Rand moved from Los Angeles to New York City, where she gathered a group of these admirers around her. This group (jokingly designated "The Collective") included future Federal Reserve chairman [[Alan Greenspan]], a young psychology student named Nathan Blumenthal (later [[Nathaniel Branden]]) and his wife [[Barbara Branden|Barbara]], and Barbara's cousin [[Leonard Peikoff]]. At first the group was an informal gathering of friends who met with Rand on weekends at her apartment to discuss philosophy. Later she began allowing them to read the drafts of her new novel, ''Atlas Shrugged'', as the manuscript pages were written. In 1954 Rand's close relationship with the much younger Nathaniel Branden turned into a romantic affair, with the consent of their spouses.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=256–264, 331–343}} ''Atlas Shrugged'', published in 1957, was Rand's ''magnum opus''.{{harvnb|Rand|1997|p=704}} Rand described the theme of the novel as "the role of the mind in man's existence—and, as a corollary, the demonstration of a new moral philosophy: the morality of rational self-interest."{{cite book |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=For the New Intellectual |location=New York |publisher=Signet |year=1963 |origyear=1961 |isbn=0-451-16308-7 |oclc=36698277 |page=88}} It advocates the core tenets of Rand's philosophy of [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivism]] and expresses her concept of human achievement. The plot involves a [[dystopia]]n United States in which the most creative industrialists, scientists and artists go on [[strike action|strike]] and retreat to a mountainous hideaway where they build an independent free economy. The novel's hero and leader of the strike, [[John Galt]], describes the strike as "stopping the motor of the world" by withdrawing the minds of the individuals most contributing to the nation's wealth and achievement. With this fictional strike, Rand intended to illustrate that without the efforts of the rational and productive, the economy would collapse and society would fall apart. The novel includes elements of [[mystery (fiction)|mystery]] and science fiction,{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=42}} and it contains Rand's most extensive statement of Objectivism in any of her works of fiction, a lengthy monologue delivered by Galt. ''Atlas Shrugged'' became an international bestseller, and in an interview with [[Mike Wallace (journalist)|Mike Wallace]] Rand declared herself "the most creative thinker alive."{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=2}} Rand's last work of fiction, it marked a turning point in her life, ending her career as novelist and beginning her role as a popular philosopher.{{cite book |title=Ayn Rand's Atlas Shrugged: A Philosophical and Literary Companion |editor-last=Younkins |editor-first=Edward W. |location=Burlington, Vermont |publisher=Ashgate Publishing |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-7546-5533-6 |oclc=69792104 |chapter=Introduction |page=1}} After completing the novel of more than one thousand pages, however, Rand fell into a severe depression that may have been aggravated by her use of prescription amphetamines.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=178}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=303–306}} In 1958 Nathaniel Branden established Nathaniel Branden Lectures, later incorporated as the [[Nathaniel Branden Institute]] (NBI), to promote Rand's philosophy. Collective members gave lectures for NBI and wrote articles for [[Objectivist periodicals]] that she edited. Rand later published some of these articles in book form. Critics, including some former NBI students and Branden himself, have described the culture of NBI as one of intellectual conformity and excessive reverence for Rand, with some describing NBI or the entire [[Objectivist movement]] as a [[cult]] or religion.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|pp=105–106}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=232–233}} Rand expressed opinions on a wide range of topics, including literature, music, sexuality, even facial hair, and some of her followers mimicked all her preferences, wearing clothes to match characters from her novels and buying furniture like hers.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=236–237}} Rand was unimpressed with many of the NBI students{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=303}} and held them to strict standards, sometimes reacting coldly or angrily to those who disagreed with her.{{harvnb|Doherty|2007|pp=237–238}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=329}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=235}} However, some former NBI students believe the extent of these behaviors has been exaggerated, with the problem being concentrated among Rand's closest followers in New York.{{harvnb|Doherty|2007|p=235}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=235}} ===Later years=== Throughout the 1960s and 1970s Rand developed and promoted her Objectivist philosophy through her nonfiction works and by giving talks, for example at [[Yale University]], [[Princeton University]], [[Columbia University]],{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=315–316}} [[Harvard University]] and [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]].{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=14}} She received an honorary doctorate from [[Lewis & Clark College]] in 1963.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|p=318}} She also began delivering annual lectures at the [[Ford Hall Forum]], responding afterwards in her famously spirited form to questions from the audience.{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=16}} During these speeches and Q&A sessions, she often took controversial stances on political and social issues of the day. These included supporting abortion rights,{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=320–321}} opposing the [[Vietnam War]] and the [[Conscription|military draft]] (but condemning many [[draft dodgers]] as "bums"),{{harvnb|Rand|2005|pp=89–91}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=265}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=352}} supporting [[Israel]] in the [[Arab-Israeli War of 1973]] as "civilized men fighting savages",{{harvnb|Rand|2005|p=96}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=266}} saying [[European colonization of the Americas|European colonists]] had the right to take land from [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|American Indians]],{{harvnb|Rand|2005|pp=102–104}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=266}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=391}} and calling [[homosexuality]] "immoral" and "disgusting", while also advocating the repeal of all laws against homosexuality.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=362}}; {{cite book |title=Ayn Rand, Homosexuality, and Human Liberation |last=Sciabarra |first=Chris Matthew |location=Cape Town, South Africa |publisher=Leap Publishing |year=2003 |isbn=0-958-4573-3-6 |pages=7–8}} She also endorsed several [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidates for President of the United States, most strongly [[Barry Goldwater]] in [[United States presidential election, 1964|1964]], whose candidacy she promoted in several articles for ''The Objectivist Newsletter''.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=204–206}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=322–323}} [[File:Ayn Rand and Frank O'Connor Monument 2010.JPG|thumb|left|Grave marker for Rand and her husband|alt=A twin gravestone bearing the name "Frank O'Connor" on the left, and "Ayn Rand O'Connor" on the right]] In 1964 Nathaniel Branden began an affair with the young actress Patrecia Scott, whom he later married. Nathaniel and Barbara Branden kept the affair hidden from Rand. When she learned of it in 1968, though her romantic relationship with Branden had already ended,{{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=101}} Rand terminated her relationship with both Brandens, which led to the closure of NBI.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=344–358}} Rand published an article in ''The Objectivist'' repudiating Nathaniel Branden for dishonesty and other "irrational behavior in his private life."{{cite journal |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=To Whom It May Concern |journal=[[The Objectivist]] |volume=7 |issue=5 |pages=1–8 |location=New York |year=1968 |month=May}} Branden later apologized in an interview to "every student of Objectivism" for "perpetuating the Ayn Rand mystique" and for "contributing to that dreadful atmosphere of intellectual repressiveness that pervades the Objectivist movement."{{cite journal |title=Break Free! An Interview with Nathaniel Branden |journal=[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]] |month=October |year=1971 |url=http://reason.com/assets/db/12563232233861.pdf |page=13}} A heavy smoker, Rand underwent surgery for lung cancer in 1974. Although she had long opposed government assistance programs, she wrote that it is perfectly moral to accept [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] and [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]], given the coercion used to collect the resources for such programs and the widespread impoverishment that results.Rand, Ayn, "The Question of Scholarships," ''The Objectivist'', June, 1966, reprinted as chapter 7 of ''The Voice of Reason: Essays in Objectivist Thought'', L. Peikoff, edit., NAL, 1990. Consistently with the advice she gave others, Rand accepted such payments for herself and her husband.{{harvnb|McConnell|2010|pp=520–521}} Several more of her closest associates parted company with her,{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=386–389}} and during the late 1970s her activities within the [[Objectivist movement]] declined, especially after the death of her husband on November 9, 1979.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=392–395}} One of her final projects was work on a never-completed television adaptation of ''Atlas Shrugged''. She had also planned to write another novel, but did not get far in her notes.{{harvnb|Rand|1997|p=697}} Rand died of [[heart failure]] on March 6, 1982 at her home in New York City,{{harvnb|Saxon|1982|p=36}} and was interred in the [[Kensico Cemetery]], [[Valhalla, New York]].{{Find a Grave|851|accessdate=August 10, 2010}} Rand's funeral was attended by some of her prominent followers, including Alan Greenspan. A six-foot floral arrangement in the shape of a dollar sign was placed near her casket.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|p=403}} In her will, Rand named [[Leonard Peikoff]] the heir to her estate.{{-}} ==Philosophy== {{Objectivist movement}}{{Main|Objectivism (Ayn Rand)}} Rand developed an integrated philosophical system called "[[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivism]]." Its essence is "the concept of man as a heroic being, with his own happiness as the moral purpose of his life, with productive achievement as his noblest activity, and reason as his only absolute.""About the Author" in {{harvnb|Rand|1992|pp=1170–1171}} As an [[atheist]] who rejected [[faith]] as antithetical to reason, Rand embraced [[philosophical realism]] and opposed all forms of what she regarded as mysticism and [[supernaturalism]], including every organized religion.Den Uyl, Douglas J. & Rasmussen, Douglas B. "Ayn Rand's Realism" in {{harvnb|Den Uyl|Rasmussen|1986|pp=3–20}} Rand argued for [[rational egoism]] (rational self-interest), as the only proper guiding moral principle. The individual should "exist for his own sake," she wrote in 1962, "neither sacrificing himself to others nor sacrificing others to himself."{{cite book |title=[[The Voice of Reason]] |first=Ayn |last=Rand |others=Edited by Leonard Peikoff |location=New York |publisher=New American Library |year=1989 |isbn=0-453-00634-5 |oclc=18048955 |chapter=Introducing Objectivism |page=3}} This article originally appeared in the ''Los Angeles Times'' on June 17, 1962. Rand held that ''laissez-faire'', free market capitalism is the only moral social system. Her political views were strongly [[individualism|individualist]], [[anti-statist]], [[anti-fascist]] and [[anti-Communist]]. Rand was strongly opposed to many [[Liberalism in the United States|liberal]], [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] and [[Libertarian movement|libertarian]] politicians of her time, including prominent anti-Communists.{{cite news |last=Toffler |first=Alvin |authorlink=Alvin Toffler |title=Playboy Interview: Ayn Rand |work=[[Playboy]] |month=March |year=1964 |volume=11 |issue=3 |url=http://www.playboy.com/articles/ayn-rand-playboy-interview/index.html |pages=35–43}}{{cite news |authorlink=Maureen Dowd |first=Maureen |last=Dowd |title=Where 'Atlas Shrugged' Is Still Read - Forthrightly |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/weekinreview/where-atlas-shrugged-is-still-read-forthrightly.html?pagewanted=all |work=The New York Times |date=September 13, 1987 |page=E5}} Rand rejected [[anarcho-capitalism]] as "a contradiction in terms", a point on which she has been criticized by self-styled "anarchist Objectivists."{{cite book |editor1-last=Machan |editor1-first=Tibor |editor1-link=Tibor R. Machan |editor2-first=Roderick |editor2-last=Long |editor2-link=Roderick Long |title=Anarchism/Minarchism |publisher=Ashgate |location=Aldershot |year=2008 |isbn=0-7546-6066-4 |oclc=85766066 |first=William R. |last=Thomas |chapter=Objectivism against Anarchy |pages=39–57 |lastauthoramp=y}} Philosopher [[Chandran Kukathas]] said her "unremitting hostility towards the state and taxation sits inconsistently with a rejection of anarchism, and her attempts to resolve the difficulty are ill-thought out and unsystematic."{{harvnb|Kukathas|1998|p=55}} Rand acknowledged [[Aristotle]] as her greatest influence"About the Author" in {{harvnb|Rand|1992|p=1171}} and found early inspiration in [[Friedrich Nietzsche]],{{Harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|pp=100–106}} although she rejected what she considered his anti-reason stance. Ronald E. Merrill and [[David Ramsay Steele]] have argued that there exists a difference between her early and later views on the subject of "sacrificing" others.{{cite book |title=The Ideas of Ayn Rand |last=Merrill |first=Ronald E. |location=La Salle, Illinois |publisher=Open Court Publishing |year=1991 |isbn=0-8126-9157-1 |oclc=23254190 |pages=38–39}}{{cite journal |first=David Ramsay |last=Steele |authorlink=David Ramsay Steele |title=Alice in Wonderland |journal=[[Liberty (1987)|Liberty]] |url=http://www.la-articles.org.uk/alice.htm |year=1988 |month=May |volume=1 |issue=5 |pages=35–43}} Reprinted from ''Free Life: Journal of the Libertarian Alliance'' '''5''' (1). For example, the first edition of ''We the Living'' contained language which has been interpreted as advocating ruthless elitism: "What are your masses but mud to be ground underfoot, fuel to be burned for those who deserve it?" Robert Mayhew cautions, “We should not conclude too quickly that these passages are strong evidence of an earlier Nietzschean phase in Ayn Rand’s development, because such language can be strictly metaphorical (even if the result of an early interest in Nietzsche)”Mayhew, Robert (2004). ''We the Living'' '36 and '59. In Robert Mayhew, ''Essays on Ayn Rand's We the Living''. Lanham, MD: Lexington Books, p. 205. Rand remarked that in the [[history of philosophy]] she could only recommend "three A's"—Aristotle, [[Thomas Aquinas|Aquinas]], and Ayn Rand.{{harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|p=12}} Among the philosophers Rand held in particular disdain was [[Immanuel Kant]], whom she referred to as a "monster" and "the most evil man in history".{{cite journal |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=Brief Summary |journal=[[The Objectivist]] |month=September |year=1971 |volume=10 |issue=9 |page=4}} Rand was strongly opposed to the view that reason is unable to know reality "as it is in itself", which she ascribed to Kant, and she considered her philosophy to be the "exact opposite" of Kant's on "every fundamental issue". Objectivist philosophers George Walsh{{cite journal |last=Walsh |first=George V. |title=Ayn Rand and the Metaphysics of Kant |journal=[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]] |year=2000 |month=Fall |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=69–103 |url=http://enlightenment.supersaturated.com/objectivity/walsh1/}} and Fred Seddon{{cite book |last=Seddon |first=Fred |title=Ayn Rand, Objectivists, and the History of Philosophy |publisher=University Press of America |location=Lanham, Maryland |year=2003 |pages=63–81 |isbn=0-7618-2308-5 |oclc=51969016}} both argue that Rand misinterpreted Kant. Walsh argues that both philosophers adhere to many of the same basic positions, and that Rand exaggerated her differences with Kant. Walsh says that for many critics, Rand's writing on Kant is "ignorant and unworthy of discussion". Rand scholars Douglas Den Uyl and [[Douglas B. Rasmussen]], while stressing the importance and originality of her thought, describe her style as "literary, hyperbolic and emotional."{{cite journal |title=Nozick On the Randian Argument |last1=Den Uyl |first1=Douglas |last2=Rasmussen |first2=Douglas |journal=[[The Personalist]] |year=1978 |month=April |volume=59 |page=203 |lastauthoramp=y}} Philosopher Jack Wheeler says that despite "the incessant bombast and continuous venting of Randian rage," Rand's ethics is "a most immense achievement, the study of which is vastly more fruitful than any other in contemporary thought."Wheeler, Jack. "Rand and Aristotle" in {{harvnb|Den Uyl|Rasmussen|1986|p=96}} In 1976, she said that her most important contributions to philosophy were her "theory of concepts, [her] ethics, and [her] discovery in politics that evil—the violation of rights—consists of the initiation of force."{{harvnb|Rand|2005|p=166}} ==Reception== During Rand's lifetime, her work evoked extremes of both praise and condemnation. Rand's first novel, ''We the Living'', was admired by the literary critic [[H.L. Mencken]],{{harvnb|Rand|1995|pp=10, 13-14}} her Broadway play ''Night of January 16th'' was both a critical and popular success,{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=122–124}} and ''The Fountainhead'' was hailed by a reviewer in ''[[The New York Times]]'' as "masterful".{{Cite news |ref=harv |first=Lorine |last=Pruette |work=The New York Times |date=May 16, 1943 |title=Battle Against Evil |page=BR7 |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20610FD3D5C167B93C4A8178ED85F478485F9}} Reprinted in {{Cite book |title=Books of the Century |editor-first=Charles |editor-last=McGrath |year=1998 |location=New York |publisher=Times Books |isbn=0-8129-2965-9 |pages=135–136}}. However, Rand's novels were derided by some critics when they were first published as long and melodramatic,{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|pp=117–119}} and they became [[bestsellers]] largely due to word of mouth.{{harvnb|Paxton|1998|p=120}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=87}} The first reviews Rand received were for ''Night of January 16th''. Reviews of the production were largely positive, but Rand considered even positive reviews to be embarrassing because of significant changes made to her script by the producer. Rand believed that her first novel, ''We the Living'', was not widely reviewed, but Rand scholar Michael S. Berliner says "it was the most reviewed of any of her works," with approximately 125 different reviews being published in more than 200 publications. Overall these reviews were more positive than the reviews she received for her later work.{{cite book |last=Berliner |first=Michael S. |chapter=Reviews of ''We the Living'' |title=Essays on Ayn Rand's We the Living |editor-last=Mayhew |editor-first=Robert |location=Lanham, Maryland |publisher=Lexington Books |year=2004 |isbn=0-7391-0698-8 |oclc=52979186 |pages=147–151}} Her 1938 novella ''Anthem'' received little attention from reviewers, both for its first publication in England and for subsequent re-issues.{{cite book |last=Berliner |first=Michael S. |chapter=Reviews of ''Anthem'' |title=Essays on Ayn Rand's Anthem |editor-last=Mayhew |editor-first=Robert |location=Lanham, Maryland |publisher=Lexington Books |year=2005 |isbn=0-7391-1031-4 |oclc=57577415 |pages=55–60}} Rand's first bestseller, ''The Fountainhead'', received far fewer reviews than ''We the Living'', and reviewers' opinions were mixed.{{cite book |last=Berliner |first=Michael S. |chapter=''The Fountainhead'' Reviews |title=Essays on Ayn Rand's The Fountainhead |editor-last=Mayhew |editor-first=Robert |location=Lanham, Maryland |publisher=Lexington Books |year=2006 |isbn=0-7391-1578-2 |oclc=70707828 |pages=77–82}} There was a positive review in ''The New York Times'' that Rand greatly appreciated.{{harvnb|Rand|1995|p=74}} The reviewer called Rand "a writer of great power" who wrote "brilliantly, beautifully and bitterly," and stated that "you will not be able to read this masterful book without thinking through some of the basic concepts of our time." There were other positive reviews, but Rand dismissed most of them as either not understanding her message or as being from unimportant publications. Some negative reviews focused on the length of the novel, such as one that called it "a whale of a book" and another that said "anyone who is taken in by it deserves a stern lecture on paper-rationing." Other negative reviews called the characters unsympathetic and Rand's style "offensively pedestrian." Rand's 1957 novel ''Atlas Shrugged'', was widely reviewed, and many of the reviews were strongly negative.Berliner, Michael S. "The ''Atlas Shrugged'' Reviews" in {{harvnb|Mayhew|2009|pp=133–137}} In the ''[[National Review]]'', conservative author [[Whittaker Chambers]] called the book "sophomoric" and "remarkably silly". He described the tone of the book as "shrillness without reprieve" and accused Rand of supporting the same godless system as the [[Religion in the Soviet Union|Soviets]], claiming "From almost any page of ''Atlas Shrugged'', a voice can be heard, from painful necessity, commanding: 'To a gas chamber—go!{{' "}}{{cite journal |last=Chambers |first=Whittaker |authorlink=Whittaker Chambers |title=Big Sister is Watching You |journal=[[National Review]] |pages=594–596 |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/flashback/flashback200501050715.asp |date=December 8, 1957}} ''Atlas Shrugged'' received positive reviews from a few publications, including praise from the noted book reviewer [[John Chamberlain (journalist)|John Chamberlain]], but Rand scholar [[Mimi Reisel Gladstein]] later wrote that "reviewers seemed to vie with each other in a contest to devise the cleverest put-downs," calling it "execrable claptrap" and "a nightmare;" they said it was "written out of hate" and showed "remorseless hectoring and prolixity." Author [[Flannery O'Connor]] wrote in a letter to a friend that "The fiction of Ayn Rand is as low as you can get re fiction. I hope you picked it up off the floor of the subway and threw it in the nearest garbage pail."{{cite book |last=O'Connor |first=Flannery |title=The Habit of Being: Letters of Flannery O'Connor |editor-first=Sally |editor-last=Fitzgerald |location=New York |publisher=Farrar, Straus, and Giroux |year=1979 |isbn=0-374-52104-2 |page=398}} Rand's nonfiction received far fewer reviews than her novels had. The tenor of the criticism for her first nonfiction book, ''[[For the New Intellectual]]'', was similar to that for ''Atlas Shrugged'',{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=119}}{{harvnb|Burns|1999|pp=193–194}} with philosopher [[Sidney Hook]] likening her certainty to "the way philosophy is written in the Soviet Union",{{cite news |first=Sidney |last=Hook |authorlink=Sidney Hook |title=Each Man for Himself |work=[[The New York Times Book Review]] |date=April 9, 1961 |page=28 |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70914F83B5B147A93CBA9178FD85F458685F9}} and author [[Gore Vidal]] calling her viewpoint "nearly perfect in its immorality".{{cite book |first=Gore |last=Vidal |authorlink=Gore Vidal |title=Rocking the Boat |chapter=Two Immoralists: Orville Prescott and Ayn Rand |publisher=Little, Brown |location=Boston |year=1962 |oclc=291123 |page=234}} Reprinted from ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'', July 1961. Her subsequent books got progressively less attention from reviewers. During Rand's lifetime her work received little attention from academic scholars. When the first academic book about Rand's philosophy appeared in 1971, its author declared writing about Rand "a treacherous undertaking" that could lead to "guilt by association" for taking her seriously.{{cite book |title=With Charity Toward None: An Analysis of Ayn Rand's Philosophy |last=O'Neill |first=William F. |location=New York |publisher=Littlefield, Adams & Company |year=1977 |origyear=1971 |isbn=0-8226-0179-6 |oclc=133489 |page=3}} A few articles about Rand's ideas appeared in academic journals prior to her death in 1982, many of them in ''[[The Personalist]]''.{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=115}} One of these was "On the Randian Argument" by respected libertarian philosopher [[Robert Nozick]], who argued that her [[meta-ethical]] argument is unsound and fails to solve the [[is–ought problem]] posed by [[David Hume]].{{cite journal |title=On the Randian Argument |last=Nozick |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Nozick |journal=[[The Personalist]] |year=1971 |month=Spring |volume=52 |pages=282–304}} Some responses to Nozick by other academic philosophers were also published in ''The Personalist'' arguing that Nozick simply misstated Rand's case.These included{{cite journal |title=Nozick and Rand on Property Rights |last=Machan |first=Tibor |authorlink=Tibor R. Machan |journal=The Personalist |year=1977 |month=April |volume=58 |pages=192–195}} and{{cite journal |title=Nozick On the Randian Argument |last1=Den Uyl |first1=Douglas |last2=Rasmussen |first2=Douglas |journal=The Personalist |year=1978 |month=April |volume=59 |pages=184–205}} Academic consideration of Rand as a literary figure during her life was even more limited. Gladstein was unable to find any scholarly articles about Rand's novels when she began researching her in 1973, and only three such articles appeared during the rest of the 1970s.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2005|pp=57–58, 63}}. The articles identified by Gladstein are:{{cite journal |title=The Extroflective Hero: A Look at Ayn Rand |last=Gordon |first=Philip |journal=[[Journal of Popular Culture]] |year=1977 |month=Autumn |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=701–710}};{{cite book |title=The Modern American Novel and the Movies |chapter=Ayn Rand in the Stockyard of the Spirit |last=McGann |first=Kevin |editor1-last=Peary |editor1-first=Gerald |editor1-link=Gerald Peary |editor2-last=Shatzkin |editor2-first=Roger (eds) |location=New York |publisher=Frederick Ungar Publishing |year=1978 |isbn=0-8044-2682-1 |oclc=4192104 |lastauthoramp=y}}; and her own article,{{cite journal |title=Ayn Rand and Feminism: An Unlikely Alliance |last=Gladstein |first=Mimi R. |journal=[[College English]] |year=1978 |month=February |volume=39 |issue=6 |pages=25–30}} On the 100th anniversary of Rand's birth in 2005, Edward Rothstein, writing for ''The New York Times'', referred to her fictional writing as quaint [[utopian]] "retro fantasy" and programmatic [[neo-Romanticism]] of the misunderstood artist, while criticizing her characters' "isolated rejection of democratic society".{{cite news | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/02/books/02rand.html?_r=4&ex=1265086800&oref=slogin&pagewanted=print&position= | accessdate = | work=The New York Times | title=Considering the Last Romantic, Ayn Rand, at 100 | first=Edward | last=Rothstein | date=February 2, 2005}} In 2007, book critic Leslie Clark described her fiction as "romance novels with a patina of pseudo-philosophy".{{cite news |first=Leslie |last=Clark |title=The philosophical art of looking out number one |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/the-philosophical-art-of-looking-out-number-one-1.835066 |work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] |date=February 17, 2007 |accessdate=April 2, 2010}} In 2009, ''[[GQ]]''{{'}}s critic columnist Tom Carson described her books as "capitalism's version of middlebrow religious novels" such as ''[[Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ|Ben-Hur]]'' and the ''[[Left Behind]]'' series.[http://www.gq.com/entertainment/books/200911/ayn-rand-dick-books-fountainhead?printable=true The Bitch is Back] by Andrew Corsello, ''[[GQ magazine]]'', October 27, 2009 ==Legacy== [[File:Ayn Rand quote, American Adventure, Epcot Center, Walt Disney World.jpg.jpg|thumb|right|alt=An engraving in all capital letters that reads: "Throughout the centuries there were men who took first steps down new roads armed with nothing but their own vision." Ayn Rand|A quote from Rand's book ''The Fountainhead'', on the wall directly across from the entrance to [[The American Adventure]] rotunda at [[Walt Disney World Resort|Walt Disney World's]] [[Epcot]]]] {{See also|Objectivist movement}} Rand's books continue to be widely sold and read, with 25 million copies sold as of 2007, and 800,000 more being sold each year according to the [[Ayn Rand Institute]].{{cite web|title=Sales of Ayn Rand Books Reach 25 million Copies |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/News2?page=NewsArticle&id=17345 |date=April 7, 2008 |accessdate=April 5, 2010 |publisher=Ayn Rand Institute}} In addition, the Ayn Rand Institute provides 400,000 copies of Rand’s novels every year for free to high schools throughout the United States. She has also influenced notable people in different fields. Examples include philosophers [[John Hospers]], [[George H. Smith]], [[Allan Gotthelf]] and [[Tara Smith (philosopher)|Tara Smith]], economists [[Alan Greenspan]], [[George Reisman]], [[Murray Rothbard]], and [[Walter E. Williams]]; psychologist [[Edwin A. Locke]]; historian [[Robert Hessen]]; and political writer [[Charles Murray (author)|Charles Murray]]. ===Popular interest=== In 1991, a survey conducted for the [[Library of Congress]] and the [[Book-of-the-Month Club]] by the Information Analysis System Corporation asked 5,000 Book-of-the-Month club members what the most influential book in the respondent's life was. Rand's ''Atlas Shrugged'' was the second most popular choice, after the [[Bible]].{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/20/books/book-notes-059091.html |title=Book Notes |last=Fein |first=Esther B. |date=November 20, 1991 |work=The New York Times |page=C26}} Although ''Atlas Shrugged'' was not listed on the 1998 [[Modern Library]] "100 Best Novels" list, the Internet-generated readers poll placed four of her books on the top 100 Novels list, with it taking the top position, while another, ''[[The Virtue of Selfishness]]'', topped the Readers list for 100 Best Nonfiction. Books by other authors about Rand and her philosophy also appeared on the nonfiction list.{{cite web |url=http://www.modernlibrary.com/top-100/ |title=Modern Library: Top 100 |publisher=[[Random House]] |accessdate=February 16, 2011}} The validity of such lists has been disputed.{{cite web |url=http://www.enotes.com/contemporary-literary-criticism/literature-millennial-lists |title=Literature and Millennial Lists |publisher=eNotes.com |accessdate=August 2, 2009}} Freestar Media/Zogby polls conducted in 2007 found that around eight percent of American adults had read ''Atlas Shrugged'',{{cite web |url=http://www.freestarmedia.com/randpoll2007.html |title=Atlas Shrugged by Ayn Rand Read by 8.1% |date=October 17, 2007 |publisher=Freestar Media |accessdate=June 2, 2009}} while a 2010 Zogby online survey showed that 29 percent of the adult respondents said that they had read the novel, and of those polled, 49 percent agreed that the novel had "changed the way they think about political or ethical issues," versus 45 percent who disagreed.{{cite web |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/News2?page=NewsArticle&id=26226 |title=''Atlas Shrugged'' Influential, Poll Reveals |publisher=ARI |last= |first= |year=2010 |month=December |accessdate=2010-12-6}} Although Rand's influence has been greatest in the United States, there has been international interest in her work.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2005|pp=66–67}}{{cite book |last=Delbroy |first=Bibek |authorlink=Bibek Debroy |chapter=Ayn Rand—The Indian Connection |title=Ayn Rand at 100 |editor-last=Machan |editor-first=Tibor R |editor-link=Tibor R. Machan |location=New Delhi, India |publisher=Pragun Publications |year=2006 |isbn=81-89645-57-9 |oclc=76829742 |pages=2–4}}{{cite news |last=Cohen |first=David |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/education/2001/dec/07/internationaleducationnews.highereducation |title=A growing concern |work=The Guardian |date=December 7, 2001 |location=London}} Among novelists, [[Ira Levin]] was an admirer of Rand's fiction, [[Robert Heinlein]] praised Rand in the text of his novel ''[[The Moon is a Harsh Mistress]]'', and [[James Clavell]] called Rand "one of the real, true talents on this earth."{{cite web |url=http://www.ayn-rand.info/cth--1697-CelebRandFans.aspx |title=Celebrity Rand Fans |first=Robert J. |last=Binotto |authorlink= |publisher=The Atlas Society |date= |accessdate=September 30, 2010}} ''[[Star Trek]]'' creator [[Gene Roddenberry]] has described the influence of Rand's theory of art on his own work,Hauser, Helen A., "Harnessing the ''Star Trek'' Phenomenon," ''South Atlantic Bulletin'', South Atlantic Modern Language Association, vol. 42, no. 4 (Nov., 1977), pp. 144-148. and novelist [[Erika Holzer]] has credited Rand, whom she knew personally, as the leading influence on her fiction writing.{{cite book |title=Ayn Rand: My Fiction Writing Teacher |last=Holzer |first=Erika |authorlink=Erika Holzer |location=Indio, California |publisher=Madison Press |year=2005 |isbn=0-615-13041-0 |pages=15–17}} Other writers and artists who have cited Rand as an important influence on their lives and thought include [[Marvel Comics]] artist [[Steve Ditko]],{{harvnb|Sciabarra|2004|pp=8–11}} novelist [[Terry Goodkind]],{{cite web |url=http://www.atlassociety.org/tni/randian-fantasies-terry-goodkind |title=The Randian Fantasies of Terry Goodkind |first=William E. |last=Perry |publisher=The Atlas Society |date=May 17, 2006 |accessdate=August 27, 2009}} and [[Neil Peart]], drummer and lyricist for the Canadian [[progressive rock]] band [[Rush (band)|Rush]].{{cite journal |last=Sciabarra |first=Chris Matthew |authorlink=Chris Matthew Sciabarra |journal=[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]] |title=Rand, Rush, and Rock |volume=4 |issue=1 |year=2002 |month=Fall |pages=161–185 |url=http://www.nyu.edu/projects/sciabarra/essays/rush.htm}} In Hollywood, actors [[Angelina Jolie]], [[Brad Pitt]], [[Christina Ricci]], [[Rob Lowe]] and [[Eva Mendes]] have all spoken positively about her work.[http://www.thenation.com/print/article/garbage-and-gravitas Garbage and Gravitas] by Corey Robin, ''[[The Nation]]'', May 20, 2010 Actress [[Raquel Welch]], who met Rand, has referred to her as one of the "all-time great human being[s]... certainly one of the extraordinary people of the century,"{{harvnb|McConnell|2010|pp=566–569}} and [[Farrah Fawcett]], another actress whom Rand hoped would play Dagny Taggart in a 1978 TV version of ''Atlas Shrugged'', declared the author a "literary genius." Magician and social commentator [[Penn Jillette]] has repeatedly expressed his agreement with and admiration for Rand and ''Atlas Shrugged''.{{cite web |url=http://libertymaven.com/2007/11/03/penn-jillette-speaks-about-libertarianism-with-glenn-beck/298/|title=Penn Jillette Speaks About Libertarianism With Glenn Beck |first=Penn |last=Jillette |authorlink=Penn Jillette |publisher=libertymaven.com |date=November 3, 2007 |accessdate=September 30, 2010}} In the business world, [[John A. Allison IV|John Allison]] of [[BB&T]] and [[Ed Snider]] of [[Comcast Spectacor]] have funded the promotion of Rand's ideas,{{cite web |url=http://www.bbt.com/about/investorrelations/newsreleasedetail.asp?date=8%2F27%2F2008+10%3A25%3A15+AM |title=BB&T’s John Allison to retire as CEO on Dec. 31 |publisher=BB&T |date= |accessdate=December 7, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.liquida.com/video/780c5f23/ayn-rand-s-atlas-shrugged-ed-snider-speech/ |title=Ayn Rand's ''Atlas Shrugged'', the Ed Snider Speech |publisher=Liquida |date=10-20-07 |accessdate=January 4, 2011}} while [[Mark Cuban]], owner of the [[Dallas Mavericks]], and [[John P. Mackey]], [[CEO]] of [[Whole Foods Market|Whole Foods]], among others, have said they consider Rand crucial to their success.{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/15/business/15atlas.html?_r=3&oref=slogin&pagewanted=print |accessdate= |work=The New York Times |title=Ayn Rand's Literature of Capitalism |first=Harriet |last=Rubin |date=September 15, 2007}} [[Shantanu Narayen]], CEO of [[Adobe Systems]], reports that ''Atlas Shrugged'' is the "one" book which has "stayed with me over the years... It's a powerful story about the importance of individuality, originality and the social value of intellectual freedom."{{cite web |url=http://www.siliconvalley.com/mike-cassidy |title=Silicon Valley Stars Remember the Books that Moved Them |publisher=siliconvalley.com |date=12-10-2010 |accessdate=December 14, 2010}} Rand and her works have been referred to in a variety of media. References to her have appeared on television shows including animated sitcoms, live-action comedies, dramas, and game shows.{{harvnb|Sciabarra|2004|pp=4–5}} Two movies have been made about Rand's life. A 1997 documentary film, ''[[Ayn Rand: A Sense of Life]]'', was nominated for the [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Documentary Feature|Best Documentary Feature]].{{cite news |url=http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/158804/Ayn-Rand-A-Sense-of-Life/awards |title=''Ayn Rand: A Sense of Life'' – Awards |work=The New York Times |accessdate=August 2, 2009}} ''[[The Passion of Ayn Rand (film)|The Passion of Ayn Rand]]'', an independent film based on her life, was made in 1999, starring [[Helen Mirren]] as Rand and [[Peter Fonda]] as her husband. The film was based on the [[The Passion of Ayn Rand (book)|book of the same name]] by [[Barbara Branden]], and won several awards.{{cite news |last=Elber |first=Lynn |agency=[[Associated Press]] |title='Ally,' 'Practice' grab top honors at Emmy awards |work=[[Ventura County Star]] |page=A01 |date=September 13, 1999}}{{cite news |last=Tourtellotte |first=Bob |agency=[[Reuters]] |title=Family dramas top Golden Globe Awards |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |page=E1 |date=January 24, 2000}} Rand's image also appears on a [[Postage stamps and postal history of the United States|U.S. postage stamp]] designed by artist [[Nick Gaetano]].{{cite book |title=Krause-Minkus Standard Catalog of U.S. Stamps |editor-first=Maurice D. |editor-last=Wozniak |publisher=[[Krause Publications]] |year=2001 |edition=5th |isbn=0-87349-321-4 |page=380}} Rand or her works have been referenced on such television shows as ''[[Mad Men]]'' and ''[[Frasier]]'', animated series such as ''[[Futurama]]'', ''[[South Park]]'' and ''[[The Simpsons]]'', and on talk shows such as ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]'', ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' and ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]''.{{cite web |url=http://reason.tv/video/show/rand-o-rama |title=Rand-O-Rama: The Long Shelf Life of Ayn Rand's Legacy |first=Nick |last=Gillespe |work=Reason.tv |accessdate=July 13, 2010}} Rand herself, or characters based on her, figure prominently in novels by such authors as [[William F. Buckley]], [[Mary Gaitskill]], [[Matt Ruff]], [[J. Neil Schulman]] and [[Kay Nolte Smith]].{{harvnb|Sciabarra|2004|p=3}} The references to Rand in these works are not always positive. [[Nick Gillespie]], editor in chief of ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'', has remarked that "Rand's is a tortured immortality, one in which she's as likely to be a punch line as a protagonist..." with "jibes at Rand as cold and inhuman, run[ning] through the popular culture."{{cite episode |title=Book Bag: Marking the Ayn Rand Centennial |episodelink= |url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4475441 |series=Day to Day |serieslink=Day to Day |credits= |network=[[National Public Radio]] |airdate=February 2, 2005}} ===Political influence=== {{See also|Libertarianism and Objectivism}} [[File:TDTP08.JPG|thumb|left|A protester at an April 2009 [[Tea Party protests|Tea Party rally]] carries a sign referring to [[John Galt]], the hero of Rand's novel ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]''|alt=In a large outdoor crowd, a man holds up a poster with the words "I am John Galt" in all capital letters]] Although she rejected the labels "conservative" and "libertarian,"{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=258}}; {{harvnb|Rand|2005|p=73}} [[Jim Powell (historian)|Jim Powell]], a senior fellow at the [[Cato Institute]], considers Rand one of the three most important women (along with [[Rose Wilder Lane]] and [[Isabel Paterson]]) of modern American [[libertarianism]],{{cite journal |last=Powell |first=Jim |authorlink=Jim Powell (historian) |title=Rose Wilder Lane, Isabel Paterson, and Ayn Rand: Three Women Who Inspired the Modern Libertarian Movement |url=http://www.thefreemanonline.org/featured/rose-wilder-lane-isabel-paterson-and-ayn-rand-three-women-who-inspired-the-modern-libertarian-movement/ |journal=[[The Freeman|The Freeman: Ideas on Liberty]] |month=May |year=1996 |volume=46 |issue=5 |page=322}} and [[David Nolan (libertarian)|David Nolan]], one of the founders of the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]], stated that "without Ayn Rand, the libertarian movement would not exist."Branden, Barbara, ''The Passion of Ayn Rand'', Doubleday, 1986, p. 414. Conversations with Rand in the early 1960s, for example, moved [[John Hospers]], the first presidential nominee of the Libertarian Party, to his libertarian views.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=185–188}} Rand has had continuing influence on [[right-wing politics]] and libertarianism.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=4}}; {{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|pp=107–108, 124}} In his history of the [[libertarian movement]], journalist [[Brian Doherty (journalist)|Brian Doherty]] described her as "the most influential libertarian of the twentieth century to the public at large,"{{harvnb|Doherty|2007|p=11}} and biographer Jennifer Burns referred to her as "the ultimate gateway drug to life on the right."{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=4}} Despite Rand's untraditionally [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] stance as a [[pro-choice]] [[atheist]], the political figures who cite Rand as an influence are most often conservative or libertarian members of the United States Republican Party.{{harvnb|Doherty|2009|pp=54}} [[Martin Anderson (economist)|Martin Anderson]], chief domestic policy adviser for President [[Ronald Reagan]], identifies himself as a disciple of Rand,{{harvnb|McConnell|2010|pp=264–268}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=235}} and Reagan described himself as an "admirer" of Rand in private correspondence in the 1960s.{{cite book |last=Reagan |first=Ronald |authorlink=Ronald Reagan |editor1-first=Kiron K. |editor1-last=Skinner |editor2-first=Annelise |editor2-last=Anderson |editor3-first=Martin |editor3-last=Anderson |editor3-link=Martin Anderson (economist) |title=Reagan: A Life in Letters |year=2003 |location=New York |publisher=Free Press |pages=281–282 |isbn=0-7432-1966-X |oclc=52493559 |lastauthoramp=y}} A 1987 article in ''[[The New York Times]]'' referred to her as the the Reagan administration's "novelist laureate".{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=279}} U.S. [[United States Congress|Congressmen]] [[Bob Barr]],{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=124}} [[Ron Paul]],{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=xi}} and [[Paul Ryan (politician)|Paul Ryan]]{{harvnb|Doherty|2009|p=51}} have acknowledged her influence on their lives, as has Associate Justice of the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] [[Clarence Thomas]].{{cite book |last=Thomas |first=Clarence |authorlink=Clarence Thomas |title=[[My Grandfather's Son: A Memoir]] |location=New York |publisher=Harper Perennial |year=2007 |pages=62, 187 |isbn=0-06-056556-X |oclc=191930033}}; and ''60 Minutes'', "Interview with Clarence Thomas," September 30, 2007. Conservative and libertarian talk show hosts such as [[Glenn Beck]],{{cite web |url=http://www.glennbeck.com/content/articles/article/198/22226/ |title=March to Socialism - Capitalism dead? |first=Glenn |last=Beck |authorlink=Glenn Beck |publisher=GlennBeck.com |date=March 3, 2009 |accessdate=April 10, 2010}} [[Neal Boortz]],{{cite web |url=http://boortz.com/nealz_nuze/2008/12/how-about-a-mini-atlas-shrugge.html |title=How About A Mini Atlas Shrugged? |first=Neal |last=Boortz |authorlink=Neal Boortz |publisher=Boortz.com |date=December 18, 2008 |accessdate=April 10, 2010}} [[John Stossel]],{{cite web |url=http://stossel.blogs.foxbusiness.com/2009/12/31/atlas-shrugged-poll/|title=Atlas Shrugged Poll |first=John |last=Stossel |authorlink=John Stossel |publisher=foxbusiness.com |date=December 31, 2009 |accessdate=September 30, 2010}} and [[Rush Limbaugh]]{{cite news |first=Yaron |last=Brook |authorlink=Yaron Brook |title=Is Rand Relevant? |work=Wall Street Journal |date=March 14, 2009 |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123698976776126461.html |page=A7}} have recommended ''Atlas Shrugged'' to their audiences. The [[financial crisis of 2007–2011]] spurred renewed interest in her works, especially ''Atlas Shrugged'', which some saw as foreshadowing the crisis,{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=283–284}}; {{harvnb|Doherty|2009|pp=51–52}}; {{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=125}} and opinion articles compared real-world events with the plot of the novel.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=125}}; {{harvnb|Doherty|2009|pp=54}} During this time, signs mentioning Rand and her fictional hero [[John Galt]] appeared at [[Tea Party protests]],{{harvnb|Doherty|2009|pp=51–52}} while the Cato Institute's [[Will Wilkinson]] quipped that "going Galt" had become the "libertarian-conservative's version of progressives threatening to move to Canada."{{cite journal |url=http://motherjones.com/print/24733 |title=And the Rand Played On |first=Amy |last=Benfer |work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] |month=July/August |year=2009}} During this period there was also increased criticism of her ideas, especially from the [[political left]], with critics blaming the economic crisis on her support of [[Rational egoism|selfishness]] and [[free markets]], particularly through her influence on [[Alan Greenspan]].{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=283}} For example, ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' remarked that "Rand's particular genius has always been her ability to turn upside down traditional hierarchies and recast the wealthy, the talented, and the powerful as the oppressed", while ''[[The Nation]]'' alleged similarities between the "moral syntax of Randianism" and [[fascism]]. ===Academia=== Since Rand's death in 1982, interest in her work has gradually increased.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|pp=114–122}}{{cite book |editor-first=John R. |editor-last=Shook |first1=Gregory |last1=Salmieri |first2=Allan |last2=Gotthelf |author2-link=Allan Gotthelf |chapter=Rand, Ayn (1905–82) |title=The Dictionary of Modern American Philosophers |publisher=Thoemmes Continuum |location=London |year=2005 |isbn=1-84371-037-4 |oclc=53388453 |lastauthoramp=y |volume=4 |page=1995}}{{cite journal |last=McLemee |first=Scott |url=http://linguafranca.mirror.theinfo.org/9909/rand.html |title=The Heirs Of Ayn Rand: Has Objectivism Gone Subjective? |journal=[[Lingua Franca (magazine)|Lingua Franca]] |month=September |year=1999 |volume=9 |issue=6 |pages=45–55}} Historian Jennifer Burns has identified "three overlapping waves" of scholarly interest in Rand, the most recent of which is "an explosion of scholarship" in the 2000s.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=295–296}} However, few universities currently include Rand or Objectivism as a philosophical specialty or research area, with many literature and philosophy departments dismissing her as a pop culture phenomenon rather than a subject for serious study.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=116}} Some academic philosophers have criticized Rand for what they consider her lack of rigor and limited understanding of philosophical subject matter. ''[[The Philosophical Lexicon]]'', a satirical web site maintained by philosophers [[Daniel Dennett]] and Asbjørn Steglich-Petersen, defines a 'rand' as: "An angry tirade occasioned by mistaking philosophical disagreement for a personal attack and/or evidence of unspeakable moral corruption."{{cite web |url=http://www.philosophicallexicon.com/#R |title=The Philosophical Lexicon: R |first1=Daniel |last1=Dennett |authorlink1=Daniel Dennett |first2=Asbjørn |last2=Steglich-Petersen |year=2008 |accessdate=August 2, 2009}} [[Chris Matthew Sciabarra]] has called into question the motives of some of Rand's critics because of what he calls the unusual hostility of their criticisms.{{harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|pp=9–14}} Sciabarra writes, "The left was infuriated by her anti-communist, pro-capitalist politics, whereas the right was disgusted with her atheism and civil libertarianism."{{harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|p=1}} Academics with an interest in Rand, such as Gladstein, Sciabarra, [[Allan Gotthelf]], [[Edwin A. Locke]] and [[Tara Smith (philosopher)|Tara Smith]], have taught her work in academic institutions. Sciabarra co-edits the ''[[Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]]'', a nonpartisan peer-reviewed journal dedicated to the study of Rand's philosophical and literary work.{{cite journal |first=Chris Matthew |last=Sciabarra |authorlink=Chris Matthew Sciabarra |url=http://www.freeradical.co.nz/content/57/TheJournalofAynRandStudies.php |title=The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies: Four Years and Counting |journal=The Free Radical |issue=57 |month=July/August |year=2003 |pages=10–11}} In 1987 Gotthelf helped found the Ayn Rand Society, and has been active in sponsoring seminars about Rand and her ideas.{{cite web |url=http://www.aynrandsociety.org/ |title=Ayn Rand Society |accessdate=October 3, 2007}} Smith has written several academic books and papers on Rand's ideas, including ''Ayn Rand's Normative Ethics: The Virtuous Egoist'', a volume on Rand's ethical theory published by [[Cambridge University Press]]. Rand's ideas have also been made subjects of study at [[Clemson University|Clemson]] and [[Duke University|Duke]] universities.{{cite news |url=http://www.rutlandherald.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050515/NEWS/505150346/1014 |title=Ayn Rand at 100: An 'ism' struts its stuff |first=Benjamin |last=Harvey |work=[[Rutland Herald]] |agency=Columbia News Service |date=May 15, 2005 |accessdate=June 4, 2009}} Scholars of English and American [[literature]] have largely ignored her work, although attention to her literary work has increased since the 1990s.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2005|pp=59, 65–70}} In the ''[[Literary Encyclopedia]]'' entry for Rand written in 2001, John Lewis declared that "Rand wrote the most intellectually challenging fiction of her generation".{{cite web |last=Lewis |first=John David |authorlink=John Lewis (philosopher) |url=http://www.litencyc.com/php/speople.php?rec=true&UID=3705 |work=[[The Literary Encyclopedia]] |title=Ayn Rand |accessdate=August 2, 2009 |date=October 20, 2001}} In a 1999 interview in the ''[[Chronicle of Higher Education]],'' Rand scholar [[Chris Matthew Sciabarra]] commented, "I know they laugh at Rand," while forecasting a growth of interest in her work in the academic community.{{cite journal |last=Sharlet |first=Jeff |authorlink=Jeff Sharlet |work=[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] |url=http://chronicle.com/article/Ayn-Rand-Has-Finally-Caught/20237/ |title=Ayn Rand Has Finally Caught the Attention of Scholars |date=April 9, 1999 |volume=45 |issue=31 |pages=A17–A18}} ===Institutes=== In 1985, [[Leonard Peikoff]] established the [[Ayn Rand Institute]], which "works to introduce young people to Ayn Rand's novels, to support scholarship and research based on her ideas, and to promote the principles of reason, rational self-interest, individual rights and laissez-faire capitalism to the widest possible audience."{{cite web |url=http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=8345 |title=Charity Navigator Rating - The Ayn Rand Institute |publisher=[[Charity Navigator]] |accessdate=June 2, 2009}} In 1990, [[David Kelley]] founded the Institute for Objectivist Studies,{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=281}} now known as [[The Atlas Society]]. In 2001 historian John McCaskey organized the Anthem Foundation for Objectivist Scholarship, which provides grants for scholarly work on Objectivism in academia.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=117}} The foundation has supported research at the [[University of Texas at Austin]],{{cite web |title=Anthem Foundation Renews Gift for Ayn Rand Research on 50th Anniversary of "Atlas Shrugged" |date=October 1, 2007 |publisher=University of Texas at Austin |url=http://www.utexas.edu/news/2007/10/01/lib_arts-2/ |accessdate=May 31, 2009}} the [[University of Pittsburgh]], [[Duke University]] and other schools.{{cite web |url=http://anthemfoundation.org/gifts-to-universities/fellowships.html |title=Fellowships & Other Multi-Year Gifts |publisher=Anthem Foundation |accessdate=February 6, 2010}} ==Selected bibliography== {{wikisource author|Ayn Rand}} {{main|Bibliography for Ayn Rand and Objectivism}} {{columns |colwidth=24em |col1 = ;Novels *1936 ''[[We the Living]]'' *1943 ''[[The Fountainhead]]'' *1957 ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]'' ;Other fiction *1934 ''[[Night of January 16th]]'' *1938 ''[[Anthem (novella)|Anthem]]'' |col2 = ;Non-fiction *1961 ''[[For the New Intellectual]]'' *1964 ''[[The Virtue of Selfishness]]'' *1966 ''[[Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal]]'' *1969 ''[[The Romantic Manifesto]]'' *1971 ''[[The New Left: The Anti-Industrial Revolution]]'' *1979 ''[[Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology]]'' *1982 ''[[Philosophy: Who Needs It]]'' }} ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==References== {{Refbegin}} *{{Cite web |ref=harv |url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ayn-rand/ |title=Ayn Rand |last1=Badhwar |first1=Neera |last2=Long |first2=Roderick T. |authorlink2=Roderick Long |editor-first=Edward N. [[CNRS]] Gold Medal (2004) |footnotes = }} '''Alain Connes''' (born 1 April 1947) is a French [[mathematician]], currently Professor at the [[Collège de France]], [[IHÉS]] and [[Vanderbilt University]]. ==Work== Alain Connes is one of the leading specialists on [[operator algebra]]s. In his early work on [[von Neumann algebras]] in the 1970s, he succeeded in obtaining the almost complete classification of injective [[Von Neumann algebra#Factors|factor]]s. Following this he made contributions in [[K-theory|operator K-theory]] and [[index theory]], which culminated in the [[Baum-Connes conjecture]]. He also introduced [[cyclic homology|cyclic cohomology]] in the early 1980s as a first step in the study of [[noncommutative geometry|noncommutative differential geometry]]. Connes has applied his work in areas of [[mathematics]] and [[theoretical physics]], including [[number theory]], [[differential geometry]] and [[particle physics]]. ==Awards and honours== Connes was awarded the [[Fields Medal]] in 1982, the [[Crafoord Prize]] in 2001 and the gold medal of the [[CNRS]] in 2004. He is a member of the [[French Academy of Sciences]] and several foreign academies and societies, including the [[Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters|Danish Academy of Sciences]], [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters|Norwegian Academy of Sciences]], [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], and [[United States National Academy of Sciences|US National Academy of Sciences]]. ==See also== *
